title: Tuesday, 23rd April 2019

For better analysis than that, here's Raymond James.

BE11:14am

The bottom line is unambiguously bullish for global crude prices and should further tighten our already bullish global oil model. Here are the
specifics: 1) Iranian oil production (and exports) have already fallen by about 1.0 million bpd from early 2018 levels. We now anticipate that Iranian
oil production could fall an additional 500,000 to 700,000 bpd from recent (March) levels. That said, we are conservatively reducing our Iranian
production (and export) assumptions by about 300,000 bpd; 2) Put another way, Iranian exports have fallen from a peak of about 2.3 million
bpd to about 1.3 million bpd. With the removal of waivers, we are now modeling Iranian exports to fall further to 1.0 million bpd, but we would
not be surprised if they fell to 600,000 - 800,000 bpd; 3) We anticipate that Saudi (plus Russia and other Gulf states) will eventually ramp up
production in 3Q19 to offset these Iranian losses. That said, given OPEC's experience with the Trump "bait and switch" last year, they will likely
wait until there is firm evidence that Iranian exports are actually falling before they begin to ramp up supply. That means we expect Saudi to begin
increasing supply in the June/July time frame; and 4) Iran will likely threaten to shut down the Strait of Hormuz but will likely not follow
through since such an action would be essentially be an act of war.

VV75 Thomas cook seems a tad enthusiastic on vague stories
BE11:14am

Our new forecast is for Iranian production and exports to fall another roughly 300,000 bpd by mid-summer 2019.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

BE11:15am

There's then a lot of blah about Japan, China, India and Turkey continuing to buy Iranian oil.

JP11:15am

And here's Giovanni Staunovo at UBS:

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Thumbs up

JP11:15am

The US administration has decided not to reissue waivers to the
buyers of Iranian oil. The current set of exemptions, issued to
China, India, Japan, South Korea, Italy, Greece, Turkey and Taiwan
in November 2018, will expire on May 1. The US administration has
indicated that Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have committed to provide sufficient supply to the oil markets. Saudi Arabia's
oil minister Khalid al-Falih said in a statement that the Kingdom
will coordinate with fellow oil producers to ensure adequate supplies are available to consumers, while ensuring the global market
remains balanced.
China has already indicated its opposition to the US implementation of unilateral sanctions, so it is probably unlikely to see Iranian
exports to fall to zero. However, with South Korea, Japan and eventually India likely to cut their imports to zero, Iran’s oil exports will
soon fall below 1mbpd. Considering the experience of last year,
we expect Saudi Arabia and its allies to cautiously react to customers need rather than preemptively ramp up production. Thanks
to overcompliance to the production cut deal, the Saudis and its
allies still have buffers to offset a decline in Iranian exports. As
such, we expect the OPEC+ compliance rate to decline again from
May onwards. However, amid seasonally higher oil demand into the
summer, the oil market is likely to be very sensitive to any further
disruptions in Libya, Venezuela or Nigeria.

BE11:26am

We think an injection of capital, ideally, is required to shore up Thomas Cook’s balance sheet. The group has been assessing various options, and the sale of the airline is a possibility, in our view, given the ongoing strategic review, but we also note that the group undertook a rights issue in 2013 when faced with similar balance sheet difficulties. The shares trade on 3.4x cal19E P/E, 2x EV/EBITDA, 22.5% Equity FCF Yield. Thomas Cook is cheap, and this news is likely to boost the (already volatile) share price in the short term. That said, we think the underlying trading conditions in the UK will be soft and would not be surprised if guidance is lowered at H1 FY19 results.

We would think that two elements of this speculation could lead to a positive price reaction: Firstly, speculation that parties are interested in
bidding for the Group (versus just Airline), given investor concern surrounding an
airline sale in a tough environment. Secondly, mention of multiple interested parties, which might suggest a potential bidding war. In December we undertook a scenario analysis which suggested a standalone valuation for the Airline of 53p per share.

BE11:28am

BE11:29am

Potential (significant) upside from a CoC at 101 for the €22s/€23s (trading at
mid 72.5/62.5, respectively, as of 18-Apr) if a bid materialises. Bidder interest
may also provide comfort around a potential anchor investor for a rights issue to
raise liquidity, should it be necessary in the coming months. Should discussions not result in a full takeover, interest from Fosun for example could also be demonstrated through new equity and an increased stake. Fosun currently cooperates with TCG in a Chinese JV to capture fast-growing Chinese tourism
demand, and contributed fresh equity in 2015 in the acquisition of its initial 5% holding. Fosun’s interest in the tourism market is also demonstrated by its holding in Club Med.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Liquidity headroom remains a worry still: at FY18 results Thomas Cook
announced that it had agreed with banks to relax credit facility financial
covenants for Q1/Q2 FY19, providing c. 20% headroom (covenant test levels are not disclosed). Management said at the time there was no need to relax headroom beyond H1, though S&P has cited headroom tightening to c. 5-10% this year and Bloomberg (17-Apr) implied covenants had been loosened through
FY19/20, though this has not been confirmed. Looking at FY18 as a proxy, after the Q1 seasonal liquidity low point, the credit facility was £50m drawn at Q2 (alongside some CP) but not required over H2, though of course a tougher
trading environment/later booking patterns could result in greater liquidity
requirements, with bonding line use also a consideration. We would become
concerned if credit facility availability was negatively impacted, noting recent disclosure that the group ‘may’ have inadvertently exceeded borrowing levels permitted by its Articles of Association (we assume this limitation will be removed at the General Meeting on 29-Apr). We have also seen reports
(Bloomberg, 17-Apr) that a £25m portion of the group’s credit facility being marketed for sale failed to find a clearing price (bid/offer was less than 60/c.70 according to Bloomberg).

through additional Casa Cook hotel openings. It is critical that the group finds the means to boost its liquidity headroom ahead of the Q119 (quarter ending Dec’18) seasonal low point, whether from an airline disposal, renegotiating with banks (for example extending lending in exchange for priority
repayment/security or otherwise) or raising equity.

BE11:45am

Umicore this morning profit warned on both 2019 EBIT expectations as well as its 2020 outlook. The
company now expects FY19 EBIT to be €475-525m which is ~10% below
consensus (€551m) at the mid-point, and down YoY (FY18, €510m). Importantly the main reason for the downgrade is the Energy & Surface Technologies (the division the market ascribes a greater than 20x FY'20 EV/EBITDA multiple), where the company faces challenging market conditions: (1) weak China EV cathode
demand weighed on by the subsidy cuts and delayed platform launches, (2) weak ESS cathode demand in Korea due to safety concerns; and (3) materially lower cobalt prices impacted the cobalt refining and recycling activities. As a
consequence Umicore now expects a 12-18m delay in the development of its EV cathode material sales and ramp up, which means the company no longer
expects to meet its 2020 guidance (FY'20 EBIT € 675-725m), with consensus (€689m) likely 5-10% too high. Elsewhere Umicore expects to deliver slight growth in catalysis and recycling, the latter benefiting from higher metal prices.

A. M. @TomD: how do you go about acquiring these skills (course? book?)?

BE11:46am

11:46 am
JP11:46am

NMC capacity build-out delayed by 12-18 months

The principal reasons for the cut in guidance are, firstly, slower demand for cathode materials in China reflecting the recent changes in the subsidy mechanism for EV's, the postponed launch of the large EV platform, and safety concerns. Therefore, Umicore does not expect to achieve 175kt of cathode production until mid-2023 at the latest (previously end of 2021). Secondly, the increase in artisan cobalt mining, which has resulted in lower cobalt prices and put margins under pressure in most of the businesses in Energy & Surface Technology. Management expects EBIT in Catalysis and Recycling to be "slightly ahead of consensus" (€169m and €138m vs UBS at €171m and €138m).

1. 2020 EBIT target (€675-725m) now likely to be achieved in 2021, given the
12-18m delay in EV cathode volume ramp up and sales. This implies a ~12%
downgrade to current FY’21 cons. of €795m, and confirms our comments
earlier that we expect ~10% downgrades to both FY’19 and ’20.
2. Umicore is seeing some price pressure in EV cathode materials in China,
given the weakening demand backdrop (change in EV subsidies), and
increased competitor pressure.
3. Sequential softening in cathode demand is very pronounced in China,
accounting for the supply chain build-up of inventories and worse than
feared subsidy cuts.
4. In Korea, slower demand for cathode materials is largely a consequences
of weaker ESS installations given the recent concerns over safety, which
will take some time to work through.
5. Capex plan largely unchanged, although the ramp of new capacity will be
slower by 12-18m. The cash flow guidance provided at the full year still
stands, with a meaningful improvement expected in working capital given
lower cobalt prices and unwinding the Hoboken issues in 2018.

BE11:48am

Disappointing guidance for Energy & Surface Technology
EBIT for E&ST is expected to be well below the 2018 level of EUR257m, a
clear miss versus consensus of EUR292m. This is due to 12-18 months
delay in the production ramp for cathode materials, an increased cost base
and the impact from a depressed cobalt price. The delay in cathode
material demand is caused by China (weaker EV demand due to changes in
subsidy schemes and postponed launch of large xEV platform) and Korea
(the production of energy storage systems has been impacted by recent
incidents). Because of the delays and adjustments to the commission and
ramp-up of new capacity, earlier targets for sales (100,000 metric tons in
2019) and capacity (175,000 metric tons in 2021) are now more likely to
be achieved with 12-18 months delay.
Reassuring outlook for Catalysis and Recycling
For the other two segments, EBIT is guided to increase this year. As for
Catalysis, the headwind from weak automotive markets is expected to be
more than offset by the gradual introduction of new gasoline particulate
filter business and growth in Precious Metals Chemistry. Recycling should
benefit from technical improvements following the recent maintenance
shutdown, improved market conditions as well as higher PGM prices.

UBS also highlighting how a roll-back on subsidies for EVs can hurt an entire supply chain, not just the OEMS:

JP11:50am

Chinese EV subsidies increasing competition and pricing pressure on suppliers

We flagged at the start of April concerns around the larger-than-expected subsidy cuts for electric vehicles in China (down 50-60% for 2019 vs cons exp 30-40%). Previously subsidies usually accounted for one-third of the battery EV price and close to 10% of the plugin hybrid vehicle price. With increasing EV competition and some OEMs already setting prices on a post-subsidy basis, this cost pressure may also be shared upstream with suppliers, something already seen in electric buses.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Double upgrade to Buy, PO GBp1,700
We upgrade Travis Perkins to Buy from Underperform, with a PO revised to GBp1,700
(15x 2019-20E) from GBp1,000 (10.5x 19E). We believe that the combination of a
stabilizing backdrop for UK renovation activity, low interest rates for longer, the planned
simplification of the business though asset disposals and the new CEO starting this
summer could lead to a re-rating of the stock. We note that Travis Perkins still has a
fairly high short interest (c6%). We have increased our 2019-20 EPS estimates by 6-7%
and now stand c4% above consensus. Next catalyst is Q1 trading update on May 8th.
Asset rotation could drive re-rating
We believe the upcoming disposal of the Plumbing & Heating business (c11% of
underlying profits) and the medium term strategic reflections around Wickes (c14% of
underlying profits) could be transformational for Travis Perkins and lead to higher
returns on capital a re-rating in the medium term. New CEO Nick Roberts is due to start
this summer and implement the recent board decisions to refocus on merchanting.
UK renovation: market backdrop stabilizing
While the UK macro-economic backdrop is likely to remains uncertain for several
months, we believe the worst case scenario is now less likely to materialize and don’t
see signs of incremental deterioration. Residential transactions are showing signs of
stabilization in recent months, with February data actually up c3% y/y on a seasonally
adjusted basis. Combining with persistently low interest rates and stabilization in
consumer confidence, this could a more benign outlook for merchanting demand.
